metadata.case_name: Sardar Gian Singh v. Financial Commissioner, Punjab

facts.text: Appellant recruited in 1927 as Naib Tehsildar in Revenue department of Province of Punjab, confirmed in 1939.
In 1946, promoted to officiating Tehsildar, posted as Tehsildar at Hansi on September 22, 1947, held post at diverse places since.
On August 20, 1952, served with charge sheet by Financial Commissioner, Punjab containing eleven heads of charges of misappropriation, misconduct, irregularities and dereliction of duties.
Deputy Commissioner, Hissar appointed to hold departmental enquiry into charges.
On August 28, 1953, served with notice to show cause why he should not be dismissed on findings of enquiry officer.
Appellant submitted explanation to show cause notice.
Financial Commissioner by order dated October 26, 1953 ordered dismissal from service.
Application to Government of Punjab to revise appellate order proved infructuous.
Petition under Article 226 to High Court of Punjab to quash dismissal order, contending no reasonable opportunity given and Financial Commissioner incompetent.
Bishan Narain, J. rejected plea on reasonable opportunity but held Financial Commissioner ceased to have power due to amendment of Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation Order 1937, order void.
Division Bench in Letters Patent Appeal reversed single judge, held rules continued by clauses 9 and 10 of Adaptation Order 1937, dismissed writ petition.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Article 133.
Section 9 Punjab Land Revenue Act 1887 originally empowered Financial Commissioner to make rules for appointment and dismissal of Tehsildars; rules framed 1932.
Section 9 amended by Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937, deleting words after 'appointed'.
Punjab Civil Services Rules framed in 1941 by Governor under s241 GOI Act 1935, effective April 1, 1941.
Punjab Civil Services Rules 1953 effective April 1, 1953 under Art 309 Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether Financial Commissioner had power to dismiss the appellant Tehsildar in 1953, given amendments to Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation Order 1937, GOI Act 1935 provisions, and subsequent Civil Services Rules.
Whether Tehsildari Rules 1932 continued in force post-1937 Adaptation Order and post-1941 Civil Services Rules.
Whether reasonable opportunity was given to appellant before dismissal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reasonable opportunity not given before enquiry officer or Financial Commissioner to rebut charges.
Financial Commissioner incompetent to dismiss due to amendment of s9 Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation Order 1937 abrogating rule-making power; Tehsildari Rules invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Land Revenue Act s9; Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937

petitioner_arguments.text: Civil Services Rules 1941 superseded Tehsildari Rules; Tehsildars under Subordinate Services Class III, dismissal power not with Financial Commissioner.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Civil Services Rules 1941 rule 1.4, 14.1; GOI Act 1935 s241; Constitution Art 309

petitioner_arguments.text: Post GOI Act 1935, dismissal power vested only in Governor.

respondent_arguments.text: Tehsildari Rules continued by clauses 9 and 10 of Adaptation Order 1937; Financial Commissioner retained dismissal power.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937 cls 9,10; GOI Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order 1936 cl15(2)

respondent_arguments.text: Civil Services Rules 1941 did not apply to Tehsildars due to special provisions in Tehsildari Rules (rule 1.4(ii)).
Tehsildars not in Subordinate Services without notification.

court_reasoning.text: Despite amendment of s9, Tehsildari Rules remained valid by cls 9,10 Adaptation Order 1937, cl15(2) Transitory Order 1936; conditions of service unaltered until new provisions; Financial Commissioner power saved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules framed under Act continued; authority not abrogated.

court_reasoning.text: Civil Services Rules 1941 r1.4 not applicable as special provision existed for Tehsildars under Tehsildari Rules; plea not raised in High Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence Tehsildari Rules superseded; notifications not produced.

court_reasoning.text: Reasonable opportunity plea rejected by single judge, not pursued.

Dissent: Tehsildari Rules inoperative post Adaptation Order as inconsistent with s241 GOI Act; reference to Financial Commissioner reads as Governor per cl7; Civil Services Rules 1941 applied, no special provision exception.

holdings.text: Financial Commissioner had power to dismiss Tehsildar under continuing Tehsildari Rules 1932.
Tehsildari Rules not abrogated by 1937 Adaptation or 1941 Civil Services Rules.

precedents_cited.relevance: Consequence of repeal: power deemed never existed, rules without jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Power of appointment includes dismissal; old rules continued but adapted.

precedents_cited.case_name: North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissal falls within conditions of service.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowered rules for Tehsildars; amended by Adaptation Order deleting rule-making power.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointing authority Governor; adaptation and continuance of laws.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India (Adaptation of Indian Laws) Order, 1937
statutes_cited.relevance: Saved rules, notifications, powers post-amendment; substituted authorities.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India (Commencement and Transitory Provisions) Order, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions of service continued until new provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition; continuance of rules; service rules.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Civil Services Rules, 1941 & 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to services unless special provision; competent authorities for penalties.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed by majority; High Court Division Bench order upheld; Financial Commissioner's dismissal order valid as Tehsildari Rules continued in force.

key_quotes.text: "the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was not unauthorised."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the Financial Commissioner cannot be held to be a Competent authority to dismiss Tehsildars, in 1953."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting view on power post-1953 rules.

key_quotes.text: "Power of appointment carries with it the power of dismissal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
